data.title: 'ext install' displaying incorrect results when there are dashes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro Insider Preview (Build 14361)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual Studio Code
2. Open your quick open bar (Ctrl+P on Windows)
3. Type in the install command for any extension with a dash in the name (i.e. `ext install code-settings-sync`)
4. Notice that the search is not displaying the correct results.

Possible Explanation:
It appears that the search term is being tokenizing as multiple words split by the dash rather than searching for the full extension name. If you search for `ext install code settings sync` you will get the same results as `ext install code-settings-sync`.

data.title: editor.wordBasedSuggestions in HTML
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

Ideally, the same suggested word to all languages, not only for languages ​​specify. For bringing "`editor.`" Tended to generalize the function. If it were a specific language being could be, for example: "`html.wordBasedSuggestions`", “`java.wordBasedSuggestions`”, “`javascript.wordBasedSuggestions`”.

If possible, I would like this feature was available in HTML, among others, working similarly to Plain Text and Markdown.

1- Suggest words that are not tag.
2- Suggest words between the head and body tags and the tag inside. Between both not show suggestion.

![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/15982252/4e1d3c92-2f59-11e6-9dbd-ce9e104e1ad2.PNG)

3- Have option to enable and disable to suggest so they are digitas. (How in Plain Text by typing only one letter). But only between tags (eg: `<h1> </ h1>` ).
Configuration suggestion: "`html.wordBasedSuggestionsAutomatic: true or false`".

![2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/15982259/6c69e998-2f59-11e6-903a-0576e7afb0e0.PNG)

4- Have the option to turn on and off to "force the suggestion" with the shortcut `Ctrl + Space` (How in Plain text when not typed the letter or how it works in Markdown) within tags (eg: `<h1> < / h1>`). Configuration suggestion: "`html.wordBasedSuggestionsforced: true or false`".

![3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/15982273/bec306ca-2f59-11e6-82a4-e05a186e2dbc.PNG)

5- Following the idea to number 4, within quotation marks (" "), but typing the first letter plus the shortcut `Ctrl + Space` to be able to show up the suggestion when there is no standard suggestion. Configuration suggestion: "`html.wordBasedSuggestionsforced: true or false`".

![4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/15982275/d03d1e4a-2f59-11e6-99e8-04e3403c8f78.PNG)

For "`html.wordBasedSuggestionsAutomatic: true or false`" and "`html.wordBasedSuggestionsforced: true or false`" work "`html. wordBasedSuggestions`"must be as true.

Best suggestions are welcome..

data.title: Support blinking cursor in terminal
tasks command environment
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OSX Version: 10.11.5

In the documentation http://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks it seems there is no easy way to configure crosscompile environment varaibles:

 `GOOS=windows GOARCH=386 go build -o build.exe`

A new "environment" property for each task would enable easier setup for go and many other compile tools. For example to achieve the above command:

``` json
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "go",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "always",
    "program": "${workspaceRoot}",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "test",
            "args": ["-v", "-race", "-port=8080"]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "build",
            "environment": ["GOOS=windows", "GOARCH=386"],
            "args": ["-o", "build.exe"],
            "isBuildCommand": true
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: JavaScript no highlight for single 'var' statement for multiple lines
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

``` javascript
var foo = 1, bar = 2, baz = 3;
```

In this case, foo, bar, and baz are properly highlighted. 
However, if you put bar and baz to separate lines, like:

``` javascript
var foo = 1,
    bar = 2,
    baz = 3;
```

which is legit syntax, but bar and baz are not highlighted.

data.title: Secure Keyboard Entry for embedded terminal?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Not sure on the feasibility of this, given that it might require either patching Electron or using some sort of native module, but OS X provides the `EnableSecureEventInput` function, to temporarily disable all other processes from monitoring/altering keyboard events. Would be nice if that could be enabled whenever the terminal gains focus, and then disabled again once it loses it. Terminal.app uses this function to secure the keyboard input while you're using it. Here's a doc on how it works: https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/technotes/tn2150/_index.html

data.title: Format Code should not change indentation of function parameters
[CSS] User-Snippets are not listed by writing single line
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Since the latest stabil release, the css User-Snippets will not show any more by writing css single line.
With multiline, works correctly.

example:
When I have a snippet with prefix "tdn" (output: text-decoration: none;) and I tip "tdn" after the "font-size: 12px; ", so my snippet is not visible in the completion list.
When I press Ctrl + Space after typing "tdn", my snippet is listed.
In VSCode Stabil Version 1.1 it has worked.

`a                                            { font-size: 12px; }`

data.title: Panels should toggle focus between editor and panel just like other views
data.body:
Current behavior of panels is to toggle visibility when
- Selecting them from the View menu
- Using key board short cuts
  Eg: Ctrl + Shift + U toggles visibility of the output panel. 

Instead they should be having the same behavior as other views like Explorer, Search, Git, Debug.
They toggle the focus between active editor and themselves.
- Easy to navigate between editor and panels 
- Makes consistent across
- Removes duplicate behavior: there is a specific command (Ctrl + J) to toggle panel's visibility
- [ ] Output
- [ ] Problems
- [ ] Terminal
- [ ] Debug

data.title: Cannot support Unicode or Chinese characters!
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 1511

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install C++ extension
2. create a c++ file with blankspace or Unicode or Chinese character in the filedir or filename
3. compile by using vscode command (use my own compiling batch script which will echo the filename)
4. garbled characters appear in the output panel, and cannot debug normally(cannot open source code file when meet the breakpoint)

This illustrates that VSCode can not support Unicode or Chinese character completely. Please add complete support to those character. Thank u!

![8888](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14960345/15968264/ccee5db8-2f5d-11e6-94bd-2c9c277fd748.PNG)

compiling batch script code:
`@echo off
rem ----config----
set directory="C:\Program Files (x86)\MinGW64"
rem --------------

echo Compiling...
set "directory=%directory:"=%"

if exist "%directory%\bin\g++.exe" (
path="%directory%\bin"
cd /d "%directory%"
echo MinGW64 Directory: "%directory%"
echo g++.exe %1 -o %2 -g3
bin\g++.exe %1 -o %2 -g3
echo Complete!
exit
)

echo Please correctly config the MinGW64 Directory in Compile.bat!
`

launch.json:
`
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "C++ Launch (GDB)",
            "type": "cppdbg",
            "request": "launch",
            "launchOptionType": "Local",
            "targetArchitecture": "x64",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/a.exe",
            "args": [],
            "stopAtEntry": false,
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "environment": [],
            "externalConsole": true,
            "miDebuggerPath": "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\MinGW64\\bin\\gdb.exe"
        }
    ]
}
`

tasks.json:
`{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "${workspaceRoot}\\.vscode\\Compile.bat",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["${file}","${workspaceRoot}\\a.exe"],
    "showOutput": "always"
}`

data.title: Implement editor undo stack serialization

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Related to #7169, #7535

Similarly to the view state, we need a way to serialize, and later deserialize, a model's undo stack.

data.title: Implement editor model content hashing
data.body:
Related to #7169

In order to be able to correctly restore an undo stack upon a model, we need to unequivocally know whether the file contents have changed since the undo stack was serialised. The only way is using content hashing.

Implementing content hashing could be performed in a way that improves performance overall, especially in loading a file's contents from disk.
- [x] Implement `IFileService.resolveContentAsStream`. This will let us receive chunks of the file's contents in a stream interface, instead of a big `string`.
- [x] Implement a `ModuleBuilder` which would be able to build a model given such a stream and compute its hash on the fly.

data.title: explore #7182
data.body:
For:
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7208
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7182

data.title: Output wrapping is broken
data.body:
We go through all that trouble to measure the height of each line in the output, by [counting the characters](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/browser/replViewer.ts#L121) and taking the width of the repl into account... and then we set the CSS to break words on wrap? 😕 

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/15966002/5195011c-2f21-11e6-877b-bfa593d5b664.gif)

You either need `word-break: break-all;` or you need to take words into account when calculating the height.

data.title: Explicitly refresh active text editor from extension api.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: There doesn't appear to be any way to explicitly refresh the active text editor. This would be useful for extensions that modify files via external commands and need to show the latest version once said command completes.

data.title: When saving all, save whatever files can be immediately saved, even if some can't be
data.body:
If I have a bunch of unsaved files open, plus one or two new ('untitled') ones and then click 'save all', it immediately throws up a dialog asking me to 'save as' the untitled files. When i don't want to save them, none of the files have been saved. 

This makes little sense; those files that can be immediately saved should be saved, and those that can't should wait for more information. The untitled files shouldn't hold up the others from being saved.

data.title: Unable to Search for or Install Extensions Behind Proxy
ENOSPC errors not showing up on the gui, but breaks intellisense.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17.4 x64

When using vscode on Mint Linux the intellisense starts as broken.
with no clear indication of there being a problem.
only after toggling the developer tools and looking at the console is it clear some problem exists and googling it brings up the FAQ.

A user may just assume intellisense is not supported because no indication of an error is displayed on the GUI.

I believe such errors should be shown to the user with a link to the page explaining how adjust the configuration of the system to avoid them.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install vscode on fresh vanilla mint 17.4 x64 (tested on 4gb ram , 2cpu core, 20gb ssd VMware player and virtualbox instances)
2. try to use intellisense functionality on a javascript project.

data.title: Stray processes left when closing the main window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-1465219835
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17.3 Rosa (4.4.0-22-lowlatency #40~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP PREEMPT Fri May 13 22:47:02 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In terminal run `code`.
2. (sometimes optional) enable built-in terminal and run `ls` in it
3. Close the window
4. Result:

```
kda@toster ~ $ code
# launch terminal, do something in it and close the window
kda@toster ~/workspace/tmp $ code
kda@toster ~/workspace/tmp $ pgrep -la code
31925 /usr/share/code/code
31928 /usr/share/code/code --type=zygote --no-sandbox
31999 /usr/share/code/code /usr/share/code/resources/app/out/bootstrap --type=SharedProcess
32179 /usr/share/code/code ./terminalProcess
```

I've captured the strace for the `code` process with:
`strace -f -o vscode.strace.log code > vscode.stdout.log 2> vscode.stderr.log`

Result is attached.
[vscode.strace.log.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/308909/vscode.strace.log.zip)

data.title: Exit on Integrated terminal with zsh.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 x64
- Terminal: Using zsh as terminal by default.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Toggle integrated terminal. 
2. Type `exit` to end session.

Terminal session  is closed, but panel is not. You can toggle many times terminal, but do not open new session, you can not use it until you restart VS Code.

Using Bash, `exit` closes the panel, and toggle it again brings a new session.
